title: Wireshark Challenge 1
instructions:
The SOC at BulbaTech Innovations received an alert of abnormal traffic patterns and a high number of repeated queries originating from one of their external-facing endpoints (172.16.1.16).

Using your newfound Wireshark skills, perform network traffic analysis on the wireshark_challenge.pcap packet capture to produce findings for the report questions below.

Challenge File:

  • 02_Network_Security/02_Wireshark/Challenges/wireshark_challenge.pcap

questions.question: How many total packets are in the wireshark_challenge.pcap packet capture?
questions.hint: Look for a section that displays properties about the capture file.

questions.question: What was the first domain name queried and resolved in the capture?
questions.hint: Try using a display filter for the specified protocol.

questions.question: What is the associated IP address of the domain name?
questions.hint: The query response may contain the answer.

questions.question: How many HTTP packets are contained in the capture file?
What is the relative path the victim accessed on the web server to request a file for download?
Based on the response header, what file type or format does the web server claim the downloaded file to be?
questions.hint: Follow the HTTP stream, and look for the Content-Type response header.

questions.question: However, what is the actual file signature or magic bytes contained in the file?
questions.hint: Magic bytes, also referred to as magic numbers or file signatures, are sequences of bytes located at the very beginning of a file. They serve as a unique identifier for the file's format or type.

questions.question: What command-line utility or program was used by the victim to download the file?
What is the sha256 hash of the downloaded file?
questions.hint: You may need to export an HTTP object contained within the packet capture.

questions.question: Submit the uncovered hash to VirusTotal. Based on the popular threat label and tags, what type of malware did the endpoint get infected with?
What protocol makes up the majority of UDP packets?
Look at the domain names that were queried within the capture. In defanged format, what is the base domain name that is continually queried?
questions.hint: It might be helpful to open up a DNS packet in the Packet Details Pane first. From there, look for the field that contains the queried domain name and add it as a column.

questions.question: Read up on MITRE ATT&CK ID T1071.004. What is the attack technique weâ€™re likely seeing in the PCAP file often known as?
